flammable_liquids.rationale: Category 2 because of its flash point: -45degC, initial boiling point: 39degC, and UNRTDG Class: 3, PGIII

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures, which in contact with water, emit flammable gases

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances with boiling point of >55degC are not available.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: It was set as the outside of Category based on that rat oral LD50 value (14063mg/kg (ATSDR (1995))) was 5000mg/kg or more.

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: It became the Category 4 to outside of Category from rabbit percutaneous LD50 values (> 2000mg/kg, > 3750mg/kg (IUCLID (2000)). but it cannot be classified since it cannot be decided.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: It is Category 3 - out of Category based on rat inhalation LC50 value (>5.2 mg/L (IUCLID (2000))), it was cannot be decided and so cannot be classified.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: The result obtained in 4 hour contact test of the agents on rabbit skin irritation with Draize's method (Draize score 4.8 (IUCLID (200)), it was classified as Category 2.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: By a statement that an eye is stimulated by gasoline vapor exposures in humans(ACGIH (2001)) and based on not irritating in rabbit eye irritation test (ATSDR (1995)), it was set as Category 2B.

respiratory_skin_sensitizer.classification: Respiratory sensitization: Classification not possible; Skin sensitization: Not classified
respiratory_skin_sensitizer.rationale: Respiratory sensitization: No data. Skin sensitization: Since a result that the guinea pig test proved no sensitization has been obtained[ ATSDR (1995) ].)., it was put ouyside of the Category.

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: It gave negative in dominant lethality test using the mouse (IUCLID (2000)), and it also gave negative in the rat marrow cell in vivo chromosomal aberration test (IARC 45 (1989)). Therefore we classified it as Out Of Category based on the technical guideline.

carcinogenicity.hazard_statement: Suspected of causing cancer (state route of exposure if it is conclusively proven that no other routes of exposure cause the hazard)
carcinogenicity.rationale: It was set as 2 based on the carcinogenic segment A3 by ACGIH (1996).

toxic_to_reproduction.rationale: Any significant reproductive toxicity has not been observed in the two generation reproduction studies with exposing for two weeks before mating to male/female rat and during pregnancy (IUCLID (2000)). Moreover, teratogenicity has not been observed in the teratogenicity test that followed OECD TG414 (IUCLID (2000)). Therefore, it was placed out of classification. [Special notes] In addition, increase in cleft palates and the number of survived litters has been observed in reproductive toxicity studies of mice, but this was the result at the highest dose with mother animals lethality reached 44%, while no statement of reproductive toxicity at any lower rate is found. Therefore, since the increase in cleft palates and fetal mortality is considered to have been caused of the toxicity against maternal animals, it is not used as referrence for this classification.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organs/systemic toxicity following single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs (lung, kidneys); May cause respiratory irritation or may cause drowsiness and dizziness (narcotic)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: There is the description that the amount of the oral ingestion and the inhalation exposure in the high concentration in human causes pneumonitis (PATTY (5th, 2001)), disorders of kidney (ATSDR (1995)), and it is classified into Category 1 (respiratory tract, kidney). Moreover, it is classified into Category 3 (anaesthetic) by the description that there are a coma and anaesthetic by inhalation exposure to humans (PATTY (5th, 2001), ATSDR (1995)).

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organs/systemic toxicity following repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Causes damage to organs (nervous system) through prolonged or repeated exposure; May cause damage to organs (blood vessels) through prolonged or repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: It was classified to as Category 1 (nerve) based on the statement that C4-C7 hydrocarbon in gasoline may cause the sensitization of a cardiac muscle, acute central inhibition, and a respiratory insufficientry in humans (PATTY (5th, 2001)). It was classified to as Category 2 (vascular) because that vascular atrophy and a necrosis are observed in the rat long-term inhalation study (PATTY (5h, 2001)). In addition, the nephrotoxicity to the male rat observed in the repetitive atmospheric exposure test of the gasoline using a rat is a symptoms peculiar to a male rat, and it is not applied to humans. (IUCLID(2000))

aspiration_hazard.hazard_statement: May be fatal if swallowed and enters airways
aspiration_hazard.rationale: Category 1 because of "human beings cause aspiration pneumonia by an oral ingestion of gasoline." (HSDB, 2004)

acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 3 from 96-hour LC50=82mg/L of fishes (Sheepshead minnow) (IUCLID, 2000).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Harmful to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Classified into Category 3, since acute toxicity was Category 3 and rapid degradability and bioaccumulation potential are unknown.
